Social Cognitive Neuroscience Laboratory

In this experiment, we are interested in how people make judgments about
other people's emotion reactions.

This HIT consists of 12 trials in which you will see videos of people's emotional reactions and guess what feelings they were experiencing. This is followed by 7 brief match questions.


Note:

• This HIT requires that you are fluent (expert) in English.

• You will need to be able to play audio in order to successfully complete this HIT.

• This HIT requires that you have a moderately fast internet connection (in order to load the video/audio media).

Disclaimer: This HIT is part of a scientific research project. Your decision to complete this HIT is voluntary. There is no way for us to identify you. The only information we will have, in addition to your responses, is the time at which you completed the survey. The results of the research may be presented at scientific meetings or published in scientific journals. Clicking on the 'BEGIN' button on the bottom of this page indicates that you are at least 18 years of age, and agree to complete this HIT voluntarily.


Social Cognitive Neuroscience Laboratory

Social Cognitive Neuroscience Laboratory





Instructions 1 of 5:

In this experiment, you will watch 12 short videos (5s each) and then judge the emotions of a person you just saw. These are followed by 7 short matching questions.

Please note that this HIT has a rather long training. We ask that you go slow and think carefully about your answers. We expect it to take about 15-20 minutes to complete.

---------------------------------

You will use sliding ranges like these to provide your responses. Please adjust the ones below to the specified values.

To adjust a sliding range, you can:

– – Click anywhere on grey bar – –

– – Click and drag anywhere on the grey bar – –

– – Click “not at all” or “extremely” to the left and right of the grey bar – –

Set the emotion rating for apprehensive to “not at all” by clicking the text that appears to the left of the slider when the mouse moves over the grey bar.

Setting the emotion rating all the way to the left (“not at all”) indicates that the person experienced none of that emotion.

In this case: “the person felt not at all apprehensive”.
not at all   extremely


Set the emotion rating for excited by clicking on the grey bar somewhere near the middle.


Setting the emotion rating to to mid-point indicates that the person experienced a moderate amount of that emotion.

In this case: “the person felt somewhat excited”.
not at all   extremely


Set the emotion rating for furious to “extremely” by clicking on the grey bar somewhere near the middle, then dragging the marker all the way to the right.

Setting the emotion rating all the way to the right indicates that the person experienced a great deal of that emotion.

In this case: “the person felt extremely furious”.
not at all   extremely




Instructions 2 of 5:


All of the people you will consider were one of the two contestants in the final round of a game show.

Leading up to this final round, these players interacted in games involving strategic deception and honesty to add money to the total jackpot, and have managed to avoid being eliminated in the earlier rounds.

In this round, all of the money that the two players have accumulated is at stake. These jackpots can range from $2.00 to $100,000.00.

Each player is given a choice: whether to “Split” or “Steal”.


If both players choose to “Split”, they each win half of the total jackpot.

If one player chooses to “Steal” while the other player chooses to “Split”, the player who Stole wins the entire jackpot while the player who Split wins nothing.

If both players choose to “Steal”, then they both leave having won nothing.


The players reveal their decisions to each other (and the audience) simultaneously by opening a gold-colored ball. The players' decisions to “Split” or to “Steal” are printed inside in balls.

Prior to revealing their decisions, the players negotiate with each other in the hopes of convincing the other person to choose “Split”.

(Again, for a player to win anything, their opponent needs to “Split”, but there is no financial benefit for either player to “Split”.)


Next you'll hear the rules of the game described and watch an example of two contestants negotiating before revealing their “Split” or “Steal” decisions.

This is the only time that audio will be required for this HIT.




Video Loading  
According to the host in this video, how large was this particular jackpot for these contestants?
(You can replay the video if you'd like to hear the rules explained again.)

Instructions 4 of 5:

Note that if one player chooses “Split”, the other player necessarily wins
money (either half the jackpot or the entire jackpot).

If one player chooses “Steal”, the other player necessarily wins nothing
(while the first player wins either the entire jackpot or also leaves with nothing).

In order to convince the other player to “Split”, people tend to place their reputations on the line, make bold appeals to their honor and morals, and/or describe the extreme consequences that they would suffer if they were to “Steal”. (E.g. “I promised my kids I would Split and they would never look up to me again if they saw me Steal”, “I would definitely get fired from my job if I Stole”, etc.)

The entire event takes place in front of a live studio audience, is broadcast on TV nationally, and is widely viewed. Contestants on the show are often recognized by strangers who remember the contestant's on-air behavior.







Instructions 5 of 5:



You'll be shown videos of players at the moment when they reveal own their decision and simultaniously learn what decisions their opponent make.
You'll then rate how intensely the players experienced 20 emotions.

For each player, you will be told the total size of the jackpot and shown a video of the player's reaction to the outcome of the game.

You will not be told what decisions players made. We are interested in what emotions the players experienced so please just watch the players' expressions and judge what emotions they were probably experiencing.
You don't need to try to figure out what happened in the game (although it is fine if you do), just report what emotions the players appeared to experienced.

Each video clip is 5 seconds long. When you press the “play” button under the video frame,
the video will automatically play twice.

Please pay very close attention to the person's emotion expressions
as the video plays.

For each person, rate his/her emotions by taking into account
the full video clip.
(We are asking you to judge the person's emotions over the full 5 seconds, not just at a single still point in time.)

If you think that the person is definitely not experiencing a particular emotion, move the sliding marker all the way to the left to indicate “not at all”. (Whereas, if you do think that the person is experiencing the emotion, even slightly or subtly, move the marker to the right accordingly.)



Let's begin!

Concluding slide 3 of 7:



After airing for several seasons, the game show had televised 50 episodes. Each episode featured a different pair of contestants playing the Split or Steal game.


How many of these one hundred players do you think chose Split and how many chose Steal?

Concluding slide 4 of 7:



Imagine that you are a contestant on this game show.

You manage to reach the final round.
The jackpot is large (nearly $70,000.00).

What choice would you make?




What do you think the other contestant (your opponent) would choose?
